H0.text: Cool, rainy fall weather is what the student will most likely expect when she steps outside after hearing that the outside temperature is 32°C on the radio.

H1.text: Cold, snowy winter weather is the type of weather the student most likely expects when she steps outside after hearing on the radio that the outside temperature is 32 °C.

H2.text: Hot, sunny summer weather is the type of weather the student will most likely expect when she steps outside after hearing that the outside temperature is 32 °C.

H3.text: Spring weather with flowers blooming is what the student will most likely expect when she steps outside after hearing on the radio that the outside temperature is 32 °C.

A4.text: Summer is traditionally associated with hot or warm weather.

A5.text: In other places (particularly in Eastern Asia because of the monsoon) it is associated with rainy weather.

A6.text: The sun shines more directly on the tropics than on higher latitudes (at least on average over a year), which makes the tropics warm (Stevens 2011).

A7.text: On Earth, temperatures usually range ±40 °C (100 °F to −40 °F) annually.
